message: http://learnpythonthehardway.org/ is written for people who don't know programming at all, but that just means if you can program something else you can do it in hours instead of weeks.
Tell me how I can transition to Python. Please....

beyond that, pick a project you can afford to spend time learning with, and start. use other resources (books, forums, Stack Overflow) to enable yourself to do the work. with a real project you'll find concrete problems that help you form the practical questions with which you can learn all the concepts.
IME writing code is always the fastest way.

make sure you have Python 2.6 or 2.7. the manual is here: http://docs.python.org/index.html and the standard library documentation is here: http://docs.python.org/modindex.html (though once you know the name of the module you want it can be quicker to google “<module> python”, for example “datetime python”)
try the online version of Dive Into Python: http://diveintopython.org/toc/index.html
and while you're learning, use ipython or bpython to try things out. It's a lot faster than going back and forth between editor and terminal every time you make a syntax error
Thank you for the helpful tips. I will make my next project in python.
Another vote for "Learn Python the Hard Way".
Easy... hire Will Smith to use his flashy thingy (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pu7NObQcOdk&feature=player_detailpage#t=10s) then learn Python
Is there anything in the world of print that is good?
